subsection_analysis.document: Claire Vallance (Oxford) Lecture Notes _ Reaction Kinetics.pdf
subsection_analysis.refined_text:
A study into the kinetics of a chemical reaction is usually carried out with one or both of two main 
goals in mind: 
 
 
1. Analysis of the sequence of elementary steps giving rise to the overall reaction. i.e. the reaction mechanism. 2.

subsection_analysis.document: Claire Vallance (Oxford) Lecture Notes _ Reaction Kinetics.pdf
subsection_analysis.refined_text:
Rate laws 
 
The rate law is an expression relating the rate of a reaction to the concentrations of the chemical 
species present, which may include reactants, products, and catalysts. Many reactions follow a 
simple rate law, which takes the form 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
ν = k [A]a[B]b[C]c... (3.1) 
 
i.e.

subsection_analysis.document: cbse_class_12_chemistry_notes_chapter_4_chemical_kinetics.pdf
subsection_analysis.refined_text:
Rate law is the expression in which reaction rate is given in terms of molar 
concentration of reactants with each term raised to some power, which may or may 
not be same as the stoichiometric coefficient of the reacting species in a balanced 
chemical equation.

subsection_analysis.document: cbse_class_12_chemistry_notes_chapter_4_chemical_kinetics.pdf
subsection_analysis.refined_text:
Class XII Chemistry                                www.vedantu.com                                              1 
Revision Notes 
Class – 12 Chemistry 
Chapter 4 – Chemical Kinetics 
 
INTRODUCTION  
Chemical Kinetics  
(Kinesis: Movement)  
The branch of chemistry which deals with the study of the rates of chemical 
reactions, the factors affecting the rates of the reactions and the mechanism by 
which the reactions proceed is called Chemical Kinetics.

subsection_analysis.document: cbse_class_12_chemistry_notes_chapter_4_chemical_kinetics.pdf
subsection_analysis.refined_text:
Rate of 
reaction depends on the number of effective collisions which in turn depends on:  
(i) Energy factor: colliding molecules must have energy more than threshold 
energy. (ii) Steric or probability factor (P): colliding molecules must have proper 
orientations at the time of collision.

During the period of 
time when [R] is essentially constant, because d[R]/dt is so much less than the rates of change of 
the reactant and product concentrations, it is a good approximation to set d[R]/dt = 0. This is 
known as the steady state approximation.
